name: K2-18
scenarioDescription:
The K2-18 Exoplanetary System


Overview

K2-18 is a star with 0.36 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.41 times its radius. It is located 124.1675892 light years away from the solar system.

K2-18 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the K2-18 system

K2-18 b

K2-18 b was discovered by the K2 observatory using the Transit method. The mass of K2-18 b is 8.92 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-18 b is 2.37 that of Earth. At 8.92 Earth masses, K2-18 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


K2-18 c

K2-18 c was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory using the Radial Velocity method.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system K2-18, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by K2.
